author: Dave Nicoll
title: Human Postcards capture southern characters
text:
Human Postcards capture southern characters DAVE NICOLL Last updated 12:44, October 14 2015 HUMAN POSTCARDS/YouTube 
South Seas Hotel quiz mistress Vicki Coats has a rather unconventional style. 
It started as a desire to know more about a stranger. 
Filmmaking couple Arie Van Der Poel and Nora Jaccaud travelled across New Zealand in a van for six months documenting the stories of those they met in brief one-minute YouTube videos they call Human Postcards . 
To date, the couple has produced 25 videos in New Zealand with the majority featuring people from the south. SUPPLIED 
Human Postcards creators Arie Van Der Poel and Nora Jaccaud. 
They started their tour of New Zealand in February from Whataroa and their first stops were Wanaka, Queenstown, Milford Sounds and Stewart Island. 
"We had this idea to travel with a meaningful project that would allow us to go and talk with strangers and pay homage to them by interviewing them and filming them in their daily lives or work and capture something special about them," Jaccaud said. 
The series features Stewart Islanders including South Sea Hotel quiz mistress Vicki Coats, whose uncompromising style received international attention when Prince Harry visited the island in May. HUMAN POSTCARDS/YouTube 
Once a technical drawer who designed navy submarines, Boris now works in the world's southernmost fish and chip shop. 
Another clip tells the story of a fry cook named Boris, who traded a career designing navy submarines for a job in the world's southernmost fish and chip shop. 
The idea was born when Jaccaud saw a sandwich man standing at the corner of Regent and Oxford streets in London. HUMAN POSTCARDS/YouTube 
John worked in the forest industry for 42 years. Since retiring, John has been seeking new challenges and recently competed in the annual woodchopping competition at the South Westland A&P show alongside world champion axeman Adam Lowe and others half his age. 
She noticed the man standing in the middle of a crowd and not being noticed by anyone, almost invisible, which inspired her to find out what his story was. Ad Feedback 
Jaccaud was an experienced filmmaker who had produced a number of shorts and had worked on projects in the United States and Europe and Van Der Poel was a sound engineer and producer. 
Van Der Poel was born in Greymouth and raised between Whataroa, on the West Coast, and Christchurch. HUMAN POSTCARDS/YouTube 
Just like his creations, Blair from the Catlins reminds us to listen to the child within us. 
He moved to Europe five years ago and found work, ending up in London where he met Jaccaud . 
Approaching people with an open mind and genuine curiosity as to what they are up to was really important, Jaccaud said. 
"We live in a world where we don't have many opportunities to speak in a deep way about our existence and what we think of the world and things that have happened in our lives, especially with strangers where there is no judgement." 
When they approached people with a genuine interest most were happy to share their stories, Van Der Poel said. 
They had almost no refusals, Jaccaud said. 
One postcard Van Der Poel remembered was a man named John in Whataroa, who they interviewed right after he won his heat in a woodchopping competition at the South Westland A&P show. 
"We pulled him away and threw him in his ute and we just had a really quick interview." 
He was puffing and panting while the couple quizzed him about life, they said 
"We asked him questions people would not dare to ask him as how is it to be the oldest man in this competition are you afraid of death," Jaccaud said. 
He had so much adrenaline in his blood he answered the questions with complete honesty, they said. 
The time that wasn't devoured by the videos was spent keeping up their social media presence trying to get people to watch the films, Van Der Poel said. 
The couple were in France at the moment where they were in talks to possibly cover the refugee camps there and produce stories, Van Der Poel said. 
"We're definitely planning in the future to come back to New Zealand and do another tour but kind of get people involved before hand . 
The pair had just learnt that they have been nominated as a finalist for the Best Web Show at the NZ Web Fest awards to be held on November 7 in Auckland. - Stuff
